page.title: Domestic responses to the 2011 Egyptian revolution

rev.diff:
Line 355: Line 355:
==Mubarak's family==
==Mubarak's family==
â
[[Gamal Mubarak]], President Hosni Mubarak's son–who has been widely tipped as his successor–was reported by the U.S.-based Arabic website [[Akhbar al-Arab]] to have fled to [[London]] with his family on 25 January.<ref name="Beginning of the end">{{cite web|author=Jacob, Jijo |url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/105117/20110126/beginning-of-the-end-for-egypt-s-mubarak-as-son-and-wife-flee.htm|title='Beginning of the End' for Egypt's Mubarak as Son and Wife Flee|accessdate=1 February 2011|date=26 January 2011|work=[[International Business Times]]}}</ref> Later reports said that Mubarak's family did not, in fact, flee.<ref>{{cite web|last=Norman |first=Joshua |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503543_162-20029614-503543.html |title=Source: Mubarak Family Hasn't Fled Egypt|work=[[CBS News]] |date=26 January 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> An ''Al Jazeera'' reporter said that Gamal remained{{when|date=February 2011}} in Cairo and was attending a meeting of the ruling National Democratic Party.<ref name="aljazeera-448">{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112734210243448.html|title=Protesters Torch Egypt Police Post – Police Post in City of Suez Burnt Down as Angry Protests Continue To Erupt Despite Security Crackdown|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=27 January 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> On 25 January, the ''[[International Business Times]]'' reported a traceless rumour on [[Twitter]] that the Egyptian President's wife [[Suzanne Mubarak]] has left for London as well.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/104960/20110125/suzanne-mubarak-of-egypt-has-fled-to-heathrow-airport-in-london-unconfirmed-reports.htm|title=Suzanne Mubarak of Egypt Has Fled to Heathrow Airport in London – Unconfirmed Reports|accessdate=1 February 2011|date=25 January 2011|work=[[International Business Times]]}}</ref> On 29 January, it was reported that ''BBC Arabic'' had been told that Gamal and [[Alaa Mubarak]] had arrived in London with their respective families.<ref name="bbcnews egypt unrest day five">{{cite news|author=Bhatty, Ayesha; Hirsturl, Michael|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/9380534.stm |title=As It Happened: Egypt Unrest Day Five |work=[[BBC News]] |date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> Egyptian State Television has denied this report.<ref name="bbcnews egypt unrest day five"/><!-- This could also use a less-transient source -->
+
[[Gamal Mubarak]], President Hosni Mubarak's son–who has been widely tipped as his successor–was reported by the U.S.-based Arabic website [[Akhbar al-Arab]] to have fled to [[London]] with his family on 25 January.<ref name="Beginning of the end">{{cite web|author=Jacob, Jijo |url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/105117/20110126/beginning-of-the-end-for-egypt-s-mubarak-as-son-and-wife-flee.htm|title='Beginning of the End' for Egypt's Mubarak as Son and Wife Flee|accessdate=1 February 2011|date=26 January 2011|work=[[International Business Times]]}}</ref> Later reports said that Mubarak's family did not, in fact, flee.<ref>{{cite web|last=Norman |first=Joshua |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503543_162-20029614-503543.html |title=Source: Mubarak Family Hasn't Fled Egypt|work=[[CBS News]] |date=26 January 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> An ''Al Jazeera'' reporter said that Gamal remained{{when|date=February 2011}} in Cairo and was attending a meeting of the ruling National Democratic Party.<ref name="aljazeera-448">{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112734210243448.html|title=Protesters Torch Egypt Police Post – Police Post in City of Suez Burnt Down as Angry Protests Continue To Erupt Despite Security Crackdown|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=27 January 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> On 25 January, the ''[[International Business Times]]'' reported a traceless rumour on [[Twitter]] that the Egyptian President's wife [[Suzanne Mubarak]] has left for London as well.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/104960/20110125/suzanne-mubarak-of-egypt-has-fled-to-heathrow-airport-in-london-unconfirmed-reports.htm|title=Suzanne Mubarak of Egypt Has Fled to Heathrow Airport in London – Unconfirmed Reports|accessdate=1 February 2011|date=25 January 2011|work=[[International Business Times]]}}</ref> On 29 January, it was reported that ''BBC Arabic'' had been told that Gamal and [[Alaa Mubarak]] had arrived in London with their respective families.<ref name="bbcnews egypt unrest day five">{{cite news|author=Bhatty, Ayesha; Hirsturl, Michael|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/9380534.stm |title=As It Happened: Egypt Unrest Day Five |work=[[BBC News]] |date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> Egyptian State Television has denied this report.<ref name="bbcnews egypt unrest day five"/><!-- This could also use a less-transient source --> ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' reported an unconfirmed rumour that Mubarak was planning a "prolonged hospital stay" in Germany, a move that would, in effect, have him leave the presidency paving the way for a face saving transition of power.<ref>[http://slatest.slate.com/id/2284189/ Der Spiegel: Mubarak Planning 'Hospital Stay' in Germany], The Slatest, 7 February 2011</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dw-world.de/popups/popup_single_mediaplayer/0,,14824659_type_audio_struct_1429_contentId_14820842,00.html |title=Mubarak may travel to Germany for treatment (07.02.2010) |publisher=Dw-world.de |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref>
